plan: I will consider testing different aggressive and defensive strategies. One round I will bid slightly below my max for both A and B (say $62 for A and $76 for B). Another round I will bid high for one and low for another ($95 for A and $10 for B, then swap in the next round). Additionally, I will experiment with evenly split bids ($45 for A and $45 for B), as well as more balanced yet non-maximal strategies to gauge others' typical bids and adjust accordingly. Documenting all results will help fine-tune my approach.

For the next round, I will explore an aggressive strategy by bidding close to my values. Specifically, I will bid $59 for A and $17 for B. This approach will allow me to test the waters and gather data on how high the competition tends to bid. In subsequent rounds, I will lower my bids by approximately $10 each until I find a balanced bid that maximizes my profit. I’ll track and analyze previous rounds' bids and outcomes to adjust my strategy, aiming for long-term profitability.

To maximize long-term profit, I will test the following strategies: 

1. High-Risk Aggressive: Bid 21 for A and 1 for B to test if lower bids on one item deter competitors.
2. Moderate-Risk: Split bids closer to values, e.g., 16 for A and 1 for B.
3. Conservative: Bid slightly under combined value divided equally, e.g., 11 for A and 1 for B.

I will rotate these strategies across rounds to gather data on opponents' tendencies and adjust accordingly.
